conclusion: To determine if the particle has returned to its starting point by the 3-second mark, analyze the velocity-time graph, focusing on changes in velocity and time intervals.

The image shows a velocity-time graph with a horizontal axis labeled from 0 to 3 seconds and a vertical axis labeled from -2 to 2 m/s. The graph consists of a series of vertical segments indicating changes in velocity at specific time intervals.
From 0 to 1 second, the velocity increases from 0 to 2 m/s.
At 1 second, the velocity remains constant at 2 m/s until 2 seconds.
From 2 to 3 seconds, the velocity decreases linearly from 2 to 0 m/s.

premise: The initial displacement from 0 to 1 second is positive (2 m/s).
conclusion: The displacement from 0 to 1 second is positive.

premise: The displacement from 1 to 2 seconds is zero (constant velocity).
conclusion: The displacement from 1 to 2 seconds is zero.

premise: The displacement from 2 to 3 seconds is negative (decreasing velocity back to 0 m/s).
conclusion: The displacement from 2 to 3 seconds is negative.

premise: The net displacement is the sum of these displacements. The positive displacement from 0 to 1 seconds is not reversed by the negative displacement from 2 to 3 seconds.
conclusion: The particle has not returned to its starting point by the 3-second mark.
